Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 08:28AM erika-canada wrote: Hi: I had my last Rad treatment 1 year ago.  I am extremely tired to the point of exhaustion almost daily. My sister had BC  5 years ago, is always tired -- was so full of energy before. Physically, sorry to say this, but really believe most of us will never be the same. I also went on an anti-depressant which I thought it helped in the beginning. Sorry, this is such a "downer"; but we should be able to be true to our feelings---on this site.  On the other hand, thank God we're still around to complain ---aren't we truly blessed? Have a great day---live life as happy as we can!! Many Hugs, Erika

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 04:14PM erika-canada wrote: Hi Elizabeth07: Before it falls out badly, my scalp actually hurt and was extremely uncomfortable. It happened 14 days after my 1st chemo. I then got a buzz cut, and after 2nd chemo was as bald as a billiard ball. However, please remember we are each very different. My problem was no matter what wig I bought, after a couple of hours, I couldn't stand it. At home I didn't wear anything on my head. I had extremely little energy and was super sick, so went out only for appointments. After my last treatment I had good enough hair not to wear anything....which was 6 months. I am now on Femora for 4 years and my hair is super thin; along with very bad side effects from it. I had IBC, and happy to be here to complain!! LOL

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 07:26AM - edited Oct 12, 2007 04:53PM by erika-canada Hi: I could have written "almost" exactly what you wrote. I find this very interesting. Because I have fibrocystic breasts, and some "calcifications" in the very back of the left breast, right by chest wall was told to have a yearly mammogram and US which I did. In April/06 had the same yearly ritual again. However, felt a lump the size of a big pea (hard) close to the nipple. Told it to the mammo Tech and asked her to tell the Radiologist. I was familiar with the Radiologist (worked for him and Radiological group in that Hospital for years). I stopped in at his office before leaving and asked him if there were any changes in the findings, he assured me there weren't. I, being in a hurry, as was leaving the Country the next day wasn't really concerned as he said it was o.k.  In hindsight, think he may have focused on the calcifications.........and me not discussing the lump with him was my fault, for sure. Tech assured me she discussed it with him, and he truly is an excellent Radiologist took his word for it. Believe  me when I say, I have learned my lesson!!!!! About 6 weeks later, breast hurt and felt somewhat "warm" to the touch, me thinking it was a cyst acting up. Returned to Canada approx 6 months later, insisted on a biopsy.... cyst or whatever............. As soon as he was talking about blood pooling as he did an Ultrasound core biopsy; I knew it was bad news. Next morning got a call from my GP to come to the office ASAP; that's when I was told I had IBC. If only I was more persistent, I believe the 6 months would have made a huge difference; perhaps lymph nodes woudn't have been involved. So sorry for prattling so much.....forgive me!! Erika
Posts.Title: Nipple Retraction lherridge Heena

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2007 02:03AM erika-canada wrote: Hi Sallyk: Geez it's nice talking with you, I could surely get used to this.  I had IBC with 3 positive nodes. I started chemo Nov/06 and finished Rads about 3 weeks ago. Before they started chemo I did have a CT (with contrast injection) of pelvis, abdomen and chest all the way to the chin. I'm very claustrophobic so didn't have head done.....with the way my memory is now probably should have...sorry, bad joke. I presume he must have seen that area, that's why he said it's only soft tissue swelling, just don't even worry about it. But, if you have been a worrier all your life, don't think I can change; not that I haven't worked hard at it. I guess you are who you are! Here, we don't get our path report. I saw the surgeon once only about a month after, she was running behind schedule and asked me to meet her at the Hospital. She had an entourage of 5 0r 6 interns with her. She said we got it all, clear margins and three positive nodes and she was gone, all in about 2 mins. But, I also know she's the best in this city.....I shouldn't be compaining; that's for sure. Thanks again!!!!! sending lots of hugs and best wishes, Erika
Posts.Title: Positive nodes after chemo and surgery nbare1952 Annaanne

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2007 04:42PM - edited Sep 17, 2007 04:52PM by erika-canada Hi Sallyk: Thank you so much for the explanation. I'm sorry but I guess sometimes I'm a little slow in the head (we'll blame it on chemo brain and femara) How do you know you have positive nodes NOW? No I didn't have a port because I'm prone to blood clots. I called this morning and will see my onc in 1 week. But, he was one that said it's soft tissue swelling, like 10 months later and it's still there?  I shall ask him again and need more info, this was very shortly after dx and I was dazed. thank you again, sending big hugs, Erika
Posts.Title: Positive nodes after chemo and surgery nbare1952 Annaanne

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2007 11:41PM erika-canada wrote: Hi Sisters on this thread: I'm sorry but I don't get it. would someone explain it very simply to me  !! If the nodes were positive at surgery, why were they not removed then and there? If this was detected after surgery.....why are these not removed now/or before radiation?? I thought that is why they do the node injection re: mapping.I'm sorry, but I would be very scared to have positive nodes remaining?? What do the Oncos' say about this...isn't a person at a higher risk of recurrence, if not, how could this be? What worries me terribly is I have a swelling on collar bone (front of neck) since I started treatment.......I feel something is very wrong but will see my onc at end of month. They didn't even radiate this spot; to be honest I forgot about it til a few days ago. Could they do a fine needle biopsy on this? What do you sisters think this could be?? Please help me on this one. Best Wishes and many Hugs, Erika

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 03:12AM - edited Oct 10, 2007 03:23AM by erika-canada Hi WENGF I'm afraid no one could give you an answer whether lump is cancer or cyst. You need a biopsy done ASAP!!!!! I had a tiny lump in the areolar region of my breast. I t was there for a few months, I had no pain. I also was sure it was a cyst. I so wish I didn't make this " self-diagnosis", I've learned the hard way...........it turned out to be IBC; and I lost so much precious time by not going sooner.  Please, go ASAP for biopsy, it is the only way they can be sure of what it was. I t probably is B9 cyst, but you need peace of mind. Best of Luck, Many Hugs, Erika

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 12:09AM erika-canada wrote: Hi: I do not have LE, but felt I would cross that bridge when I get there. One week after radiation I was on a plane. I had a mastectomy with a big slab taken from underarm to waist...I had 3 positive nodes. I love seeing places..travel always had been my priority...now even more. Want to see all I can. I know I'm blessed with lack of LE. Had an Onco appt day after I flew, she said not enough to worry about...just forget about it. Also have swollen ankles a few days after flying. Maybe I'm stupid, I have enough worries without adding to them...I'll deal with it when I get there. With IBC, I'm happy doing what I love, as much as I can afford....Laugh. I just want to spend my times that I'm blessed with, doing this. After 34 years of work and this horid journey...being happy is my priority. This site has helped me so especially during the treatment of Taxotere, you all are my angels on earth. Thank you....Thank you God!! Big Hugs, Erika

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 10:58AM erika-canada wrote: Hi: I believe your blisters are THRUSH, I got it after every chemo. Especially, bad after Taxotere...felt like I had a toothache in every tooth, gums were so swollen. Fluconozole (anti-biotic) helped and also Koolstat (a Cortisone rinse and gargle). I sympathize with you, as I've been there. But guess what? You'll be just fine, Bootface will not be winning; as we won't let him!!!! Be Strong Hugs and well wishes, Erika
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2007 08:38AM - edited Sep 14, 2007 10:53AM by erika-canada Hi Sue: I had a radical mastectomy with all nodes removed, left side. everybody is different........but not once,even in the hospital did I take anything for pain. under the arm was very uncomfortable..most of the rest was numb. As the other Lady said, the arm exercises are most important. I don't have 100% movement, but am totally happy with what I have. Still do the stretch (arm) exercises; I had the surgery May 15th.......but only finished rads 3 weeks ago. had some problem with the incision healing........but I got the chemo BEFORE the surgery. of course my system was all run down. You'll be fine with surgery; don't spend loads of time worrying. However, I couldn't stop crying in the OR before surgery I was soooooo afraid. i think fear, especially of the unknown, is our biggest enemy. sorry, my dear ladies for prattling on and on!!!! Sue, please keep us posted we will be there for you!!!! 1 inch = 2.54 cm. Best wishes and hugs, erika
